title: December 10
description:
Dean and Lucie left the kids with Babushka and spent a few days in the snowy north: Dublin, Ireland!

We didn't EXPECT it to be snowy, and the good people of Dublin sure weren't expecting it either, but it lent a festive Christmassy air to a fantastic trip.

children.title: Liffey At Night
children.description:
We weren't sure what to expect of Dublin. We had heard of the Irish tiger's economic growth, and we had heard of the crash, and we had heard of the friendly beer-loving pub-going people, the poets musicians and blarney-tellers. But how did it all fit together?

Well, walking around Dublin felt like walking around Boston. Same Georgian and brick architecture, same hustle and bustle. Very cosmopolitan. Here you can see the Dublin skyline has some pretty impressive modern buildings and bridges.

children.title: Carol Kids
children.description:
The feeling of being in an American city increases when listening to high schoolers carolling Jingle Bells and Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.

Same traditions, same songs, same school uniforms.

children.title: Scroogalicious
children.description:
To deepen our Christmas spirit, we went to see A Christmas Carol (you know, the one with Ebenezer Scrooge). Half the town was there. We were expecting a tradition-soaked old theater but instead got this cosmopolitan confection of steel and glass angles.

A Christmas Carol, though, was the same as it aways has been and always will be. Mmm, comfort theater.

children.title: St. Stephen's Not So Green
children.description:
St. Stephen's Green, in the heart of Dublin, is usually described as verdant, lush, and lake-filled.

Two weeks of arctic weather had transformed it into an ice rink.

children.title: Not So Green 2
children.description:
Dubliners don't do snow. They aren't prepared for it. To a person, they had nothing good to say about the cold snap that had partially immobilized their country.

Most sidewalks and many roads, even in the center of the capital, were covered with inches of impenetrable ice. Dangerous for some. Difficult for many. But we, staying in our cosy hotel within walking distance of everything, thought it was festive.

children.title: Intrepid Aviators
children.description: A motley collection of birds congregate near the one unfrozen bit of lake.

children.title: Fag on Crag
children.description:
Oscar Wilde sits on a frozen rock near the bone-chilled ducks, surveying Dublin with a smirk.

The LAST time Oscar was in Dublin he was convicted of gross indecency with other men and imprisoned for two years' hard labor. Surely it's the sign of a new and sophisticated Ireland that Oscar Wilde now so smirkily reclines, and is affectionately called the Fag on the Crag?

children.title: St. Arthur's Holy Gate
children.description:
Once you strip away Dublin's shiny new buildings, flaming statues and people on the street talking about Estonian bond issues, you're left with a country that likes beer more than just a little bit.

This is the Guinness Storehouse at the St James's Gate Brewery. It's the center of a religion, sort of like if you dropped the Christ Church and St. Patrick's cathedrals into a hoppy, yeasty oak cask.

There ARE other beers in Irelandâ€¦. it's just that we didn't see anyone drinking them.

children.title: Adwoman
children.description:
The Guinness museum is six stories of the story of Irish happiness.

Lucie in particular loved the floor devoted to marketing: she worked on Guinness ads while attending design school in Paris.

children.title: Yeast Heist
children.description: Dean takes a crack at the original yeast.

children.title: Beer Mustache
children.description:
I've said it before and I'll say it again: nothing cuts the chill of a snowy Dublin day like a pint of Guinness straight from Arthur's original brewery.

We actually saw the Guinness brewery's master brewer having lunch here (we recognized him from the videos in the museum). He was drinking water not beer with his mussels. And, contrary to expectations, he sported no halo.

children.title: Girlie Drink
children.description:
Lucie doesn't like beer.

But after a few days of Irish stew, coddle and soda bread, she was willing to admit that certain foods were enhanced by a discreet application of Guinness to the taste buds.

children.title: Kilmainham Gaol
children.description:
Kilmainham Gaol played a central role in the events leading to the liberation of Ireland from England in 1922. Belfast and Northern Ireland remained part of Great Britain.

People in Dublin (at least, the ones we talked to in pubs) refer to Northern Ireland simply as part of Ireland. There's a matter-of-fact feeling that it will happen, it HAS to happen -- not soon, but it will come.

These discussions in pubs tend to run past closing time and involve enormous quantities of alcohol.

children.title: Leprechaun Museum
children.description:
Oh no, Lucie fell into a leprechaun hole!

While she's in there, can she fetch a magic shamrock hangover cure for Dean?

children.title: Tart with Cart
children.description:
The song Molly Malone tells the tragic tale of a beautiful fishmonger who plied her trade on the streets of Dublin. It's now a national sporting anthem.

It is honored by this statue on Grafton street, also known as the Tart with the Cart.
